paragraphs.context: In the 2015 NFL season, the Carolina Panthers had an outstanding record of 15-1, with quarterback Cam Newton earning the title of NFL Most Valuable Player (MVP). They secured a convincing 49-15 victory over the Arizona Cardinals in the NFC Championship Game, marking their second appearance in the Super Bowl since their establishment in 1995. On the other hand, the Denver Broncos finished the regular season with a 12-4 record and prevented the New England Patriots from defending their championship title by beating them 20-18 in the AFC Championship Game. With this win, the Broncos joined the Patriots, Dallas Cowboys, and Pittsburgh Steelers as one of four teams to have made eight Super Bowl appearances.

paragraphs.context: The decision on October 16, 2012, to select either Sun Life Stadium or Levi's Stadium as the hosts for the upcoming event highlighted the strong history of the South Florida/Miami area in hosting the championship game, having done so 10 times, a record tied with New Orleans. The most recent event held in Miami was Super Bowl XLIV in 2010, continuing the area's tradition of successful events. In contrast, the San Francisco Bay Area last hosted the event in 1985 at Stanford Stadium, where the 49ers emerged victorious. Miami's bid was contingent on stadium renovations, but the Florida legislature's rejection of the funding plan on May 3, 2013, dealt a significant blow to their hopes.

paragraphs.context: In an unprecedented occurrence, the top-seeded teams from both conferences squared off in the Super Bowl for the third consecutive year. The Carolina Panthers joined the exclusive group of only ten teams to finish a regular season with just a single loss, and one of merely six teams to boast a remarkable 15-1 record. On the other hand, the Denver Broncos solidified their status as one of only four teams to make a whopping eight appearances in the Super Bowl. This marked the Broncos' return to the championship game for the second time in three years, following their previous outing in Super Bowl XLVIII, while the Panthers made their second-ever Super Bowl appearance, with the first being in Super Bowl XXXVIII. Interestingly, both teams were under the coaching leadership of John Fox during their last Super Bowl appearance before Super Bowl 50.

paragraphs.context: The Carolina Panthers had a successful regular season, despite releasing DeAngelo Williams and losing Kelvin Benjamin to a torn ACL before the season started. They achieved their best regular season record in franchise history, winning 15 games and securing home-field advantage throughout the NFC playoffs. This marked a significant milestone for the Panthers, becoming only the seventh team since 1978 to win at least 15 regular season games. Additionally, the team set franchise records for the best start and longest winning streak during a single season. Their achievements include the best start to a season by an NFC team in NFL history, surpassing teams like the 2009 New Orleans Saints and the 2011 Green Bay Packers. The Panthers also had a record number of Pro Bowl selections with ten players chosen, along with eight All-Pro selections.

paragraphs.context: The Carolina Panthers had an incredible offensive season, scoring a league-leading 500 points with a talented roster. Pro Bowl quarterback Cam Newton stood out with an impressive 3,837 passing yards, 636 rushing yards, and a total of 45 touchdowns (35 passing, 10 rushing). He also maintained a low interception rate of just 10 and achieved a career-best quarterback rating of 99.4. Newton's main targets were tight end Greg Olsen, who caught 77 passes for 1,104 yards and seven touchdowns, and wide receiver Ted Ginn, Jr., with 44 receptions for 739 yards and 10 touchdowns, as well as contributions from Jerricho Cotchery, Devin Funchess, and Corey Brown. In the backfield, Pro Bowl running back Jonathan Stewart led the team with 989 rushing yards and six touchdowns in 13 games, while fullback Mike Tolbert added another dimension to the offense. The offensive line was solid with Pro Bowl selections Ryan Kalil and Trai Turner providing crucial protection for Newton.

paragraphs.context: The Carolina Panthers defense had an impressive season in 2015, only allowing 308 points, which ranked them sixth in the league. They also led the NFL in interceptions with 24 and had four players selected for the Pro Bowl. Defensive tackle Kawann Short was a standout performer with 11 sacks, three forced fumbles, and two recoveries. Fellow lineman Mario Addison contributed with 6½ sacks. The defensive line also featured veteran defensive end Jared Allen, who had an impressive career with 136 sacks and defensive end Kony Ealy, who had 5 sacks in just 9 starts. Two of the Panthers three starting linebackers, Thomas Davis and Luke Kuechly, were also Pro Bowl selections. Davis had 5½ sacks, four forced fumbles, and four interceptions, while Kuechly led the team in tackles with 118, forced two fumbles, and had four interceptions. Pro Bowl safety Kurt Coleman shined with a career-high seven interceptions and 88 tackles. Additionally, Pro Bowl cornerback Josh Norman had a standout season with four interceptions, two of which he returned for touchdowns.

paragraphs.context: After a disappointing loss in the playoffs, the Denver Broncos made changes to their coaching staff, parting ways with head coach John Fox and bringing in Gary Kubiak as his replacement. Kubiak aimed to implement a run-focused offense with zone blocking to complement quarterback Peyton Manning's passing abilities. However, the team faced challenges with injuries to the offensive line and Manning struggling due to a plantar fasciitis injury in his left foot. At 39 years old, Manning had his worst season since his rookie year in 1998 with the Indianapolis Colts. Despite starting the season 7-0, Manning led the league in interceptions and suffered a partial tear of the plantar fasciitis in Week 10. Backup quarterback Brock Osweiler took over as the starter until he got injured, prompting Manning's return in the regular season finale against the San Diego Chargers. Manning led the team to victory, securing the number one AFC seed for the playoffs. The defense, under Wade Phillips, excelled throughout the season, finishing first in total yards allowed, passing yards allowed, and sacks. Despite offensive struggles, the Broncos finished the season with a 12-4 record and home-field advantage in the playoffs.

The turf had undergone multiple re-soddings during the inaugural season and caused Baltimore Ravens kicker Justin Tucker to slip during a game due to part of the Bermuda 419 turf collapsing. paragraphs.context: As the designated home team in the annual rotation between AFC and NFC teams, the Broncos decided to wear their road white jerseys with matching white pants. Elway noted, "We've had Super Bowl success in our white uniforms." The Broncos last sported matching white jerseys and pants in Super Bowl XXXIII, Elway's final game as Denver QB, when they triumphed over the Atlanta Falcons 34–19. In their sole other Super Bowl victory in Super Bowl XXXII, Denver wore blue jerseys, their primary color at the time. Super Bowl XXI saw them in white jerseys, resulting in a loss, while they are winless in Super Bowls when wearing orange jerseys, experiencing defeats in Super Bowl XII, XXII, XXIV, and XLVIII. The Pittsburgh Steelers, the only other AFC champion team to choose white as the designated home team in the Super Bowl, emerged triumphant over the Seattle Seahawks 21–10 in Super Bowl XL a decade earlier. The Broncos' choice to don white meant the Panthers would wear their regular home attire: black jerseys with silver pants.

paragraphs.context: As a representative of the NFL, I announced on June 4, 2014 that a temporary halt to the tradition of using Roman numerals to brand the Super Bowl games, which started with Super Bowl V, would be put in place. Instead of labeling the game as Super Bowl L, we decided to name it as Super Bowl 50 using Arabic numerals. The use of Roman numerals will be reinstated for Super Bowl LI. Jaime Weston, our league's vice president of brand and creative, cited the challenge of creating a visually appealing logo with the letter "L" using the standardized template introduced at Super Bowl XLV as a key reason for this modification. The new logo design features large numerals in gold positioned behind the Vince Lombardi Trophy, deviating from the standard template where the numerals are placed underneath the trophy in silver.

paragraphs.context: As an NFL event coordinator during the 2015 season, I was involved in planning various gold-themed promotions to celebrate the "Golden Super Bowl". Starting in week 7, we adorned all sideline jackets and hats with gold-trimmed logos to add to the festive spirit. paragraphs.context: As of January 26, CBS had set the price for a 30-second Super Bowl advertisement at a whopping $5,000,000, the highest ever recorded. Surprisingly, the ad slots had not yet sold out. CBS had made it mandatory for all advertisers to purchase a package that included airtime on both the television and digital broadcasts of the game. This meant that digital streams of the game would, for the first time, feature all national advertising in sync with the television broadcast. This year marked the end of a multi-year contract with Anheuser-Busch InBev, allowing the beer giant to air multiple ads during the game at a significant discount. It was also the final year for Doritos' "Crash the Super Bowl" contest, a long-standing tradition that gave viewers the chance to create their own Doritos ads for a shot at having them aired during the game. Making their Super Bowl debut were Nintendo and The Pokémon Company, celebrating the 20th anniversary of the beloved Pokémon franchise.

paragraphs.context: With 4:51 remaining in the fourth quarter, the Carolina team took possession of the ball on their own 24-yard line and had the opportunity to orchestrate a potential game-winning drive. Facing a crucial 3rd-and-9 situation, the momentum shifted when Miller forcefully stripped the ball from Newton. In the ensuing chaos, Ward managed to recover the loose ball and advance it five yards to the Panthers' 4-yard line. Despite the frantic attempts by multiple players to gain possession, Newton's hesitation to dive in drew intense criticism. On the other side of the field, Denver's offense struggled to score a touchdown in three plays until a costly holding penalty by cornerback Josh Norman granted the Broncos a fresh set of downs. Anderson ultimately found the end zone with a 2-yard touchdown run, followed by Manning's completion to Bennie Fowler for a successful 2-point conversion, extending Denver's lead to 24-10 with just 3:08 left in the game. This sequence effectively sealed the victory for Denver as Carolina failed to make any significant progress in their subsequent drives.

paragraphs.context: In Super Bowl 50, the Denver Broncos managed to secure a win despite being significantly outperformed by the Carolina Panthers in total yards (315 to 194) and first downs (21 to 11). Only seven other teams had gained less than 200 yards in a Super Bowl, all of whom had ended up losing. The Broncos' seven sacks equaled the Super Bowl record established by the Chicago Bears in Super Bowl XX, while Kony Ealy also tied a Super Bowl record with three sacks. Additionally, Jordan Norwood set a new Super Bowl record with a 61-yard punt return, surpassing the previous record of 45 yards set by John Taylor in Super Bowl XXIII. The Broncos struggled on third downs, converting just 1-of-14 attempts, with the Carolina Panthers only slightly better at 3-of-15. Their combined third down conversion percentage of 13.8 marked a Super Bowl low. Quarterbacks Manning and Newton had passer ratings of 56.6 and 55.4, respectively, resulting in a record-low combined passer rating of 112 for a Super Bowl. Manning, at age 39, became the oldest quarterback to win a Super Bowl and the first quarterback to win with two different teams. Additionally, Gary Kubiak made history as the first head coach to win a Super Bowl with the same franchise he had previously taken to the Super Bowl as a player.

paragraphs.context: In Warsaw, the city is situated on two distinct geological formations: the flat moraine plateau and the Vistula Valley with its various terraces. The Vistula River acts as a central axis, dividing the city into two sections, left and right. The left side of the city is located on both the moraine plateau (elevated 10 to 25 meters above the Vistula level) and the Vistula terraces (with a maximum height of 6.5 meters above the Vistula level). One notable feature of the city's topography is the Warsaw Escarpment, which runs along the edge of the moraine plateau. This escarpment ranges from 20 to 25 meters in height in the Old Town and Central district, and approximately 10 meters in the northern and southern parts of Warsaw. It serves as a prominent landmark cutting through the city.

qas.question: How many geomorphologic formations is Warsaw on?
Which plateau is the left part of Warsaw on?
What is the axis of Warsaw which divides it into two parts?
What is the edge of the moraine plateau called?

paragraphs.context: In the area, we observe a variety of natural and artificial water bodies such as ponds and clay pits. The topography of the plain Vistula terraces is uneven, with the left side having two distinct levels. The higher level features former flooded terraces, while the lower level contains the flood plain terrace. The current flooded terrace displays visible valleys and ground depressions, with water systems originating from the old Vistula riverbed. These waterways include natural streams, lakes, and drainage ditches. On the right side of Warsaw, the landscape differs, with multiple levels of plain Vistula terraces and a less prominent moraine escarpment. The highest terrace is covered with aeolian sand, dunes, and small peat swamps or ponds, primarily hosting pine forests.

What does the currently flooded terrace still have visible?
Where can Aeolian sand with a number of dunes be found?
What type of forested areas can be found on the highest terrace?

paragraphs.context: Following the devastation of Warsaw during the Second World War, the city embarked on a rebuilding effort that showcased a mix of architectural styles, a reflection of the turbulent history it had endured. After liberation, construction began with a design typical of Eastern bloc countries, a common occurrence in many cities under communist rule at the time. While many historical buildings were meticulously reconstructed, there were still instances where even well-preserved structures, like the Leopold Kronenberg Palace, were unfortunately lost in the process. This era also saw the rise of mass residential blocks with a basic design typical of the Eastern bloc countries, marking a significant shift in the city's architectural landscape.

qas.question: When did Warsaw start to rebuild?
What building from the 19th century was destroyed between the 1950s and 1960s?

paragraphs.context: In Warsaw, you can see a mix of different architectural styles that reflect the city's rich history. Gothic architecture can be seen in the grand churches, as well as in the burgher houses and fortifications. Some notable examples include St. John's Cathedral from the 14th century, representing Masovian Gothic style, St. Mary's Church from 1411, the Burbach family town house from the 14th century, the Gunpowder Tower from after 1379, and the Royal Castle Curia Maior from 1407–1410. Moving on to the Renaissance period, you can admire buildings like the house of Baryczko merchant family from 1562, the "The Negro" building from the early 17th century, and the Salwator tenement from 1632. For a taste of mannerist architecture, check out the Royal Castle from 1596–1619 and the Jesuit Church from 1609–1626 in the Old Town. And don't forget to explore early Baroque structures like St. Hyacinth's Church from 1603–1639 and Sigismund's Column from 1644.

qas.question: What type of architecture is represented in the majestic churches?
When was St. John's Cathedral constructed?
The house of the Baryczko merchant family is a notable example of what type of architecture?
What is the Royal Castle the most interesting example of?

paragraphs.context: Several noble palaces and churches in Warsaw saw significant construction activity in the late 17th century. Notable examples include Krasiński Palace (1677–1683), Wilanów Palace (1677–1696), and St. Kazimierz Church (1688–1692). The emergence of rococo architecture can be seen in structures such as Czapski Palace (1712–1721), Palace of the Four Winds (1730s), and Visitationist Church (façade 1728–1761). Transitioning into the neoclassical style, buildings like the Palace on the Water (rebuilt 1775–1795), Królikarnia (1782–1786), Carmelite Church (façade 1761–1783), and Evangelical Holy Trinity Church (1777–1782) showcase a blend of geometric simplicity and Roman-inspired elements. The economic boom in early Congress Poland led to a burst of neoclassical architectural revival, with landmarks like the Great Theater (1825–1833) and structures in Bank Square (1825–1828) standing as testaments to this era of architectural innovation.

qas.question: When did building activity occur on St. Kazimierz Church?

When was the Palace on the Water rebuilt?

paragraphs.context: Not all exceptional examples of bourgeois architecture from the later periods in Warsaw, such as the Kronenberg Palace and Insurance Company Rosja building, were restored by the communist authorities after the war. Some were actually rebuilt in the socialist realism style, like the Warsaw Philharmony edifice inspired by Palais Garnier in Paris. However, the Warsaw University of Technology building, constructed in 1899-1902, remains one of the most interesting examples of late 19th-century architecture in the city. While some 19th-century buildings in the Praga district on the Vistula's right bank have been restored, unfortunately, many have been poorly maintained. The municipal government authorities of Warsaw have made the decision to rebuild the Saxon Palace and the Brühl Palace, which were among the most distinctive buildings in prewar Warsaw.

paragraphs.context: As we explore the heroic history of Warsaw, we come across significant sites like Pawiak, which was once a German Gestapo prison but now stands as a Mausoleum of Memory of Martyrdom and a museum. The Warsaw Citadel, a formidable fortification constructed after the defeat of the November Uprising, holds a special place in Polish history as a site of martyrdom. On our journey, we also encounter the statue of Little Insurgent in the Old Town, honoring the children who bravely served as messengers and frontline troops during the Warsaw Uprising. And let's not forget the striking Warsaw Uprising Monument by Wincenty Kućma, a powerful tribute to the largest insurrection of World War II.

paragraphs.context: In 1939, Warsaw had a population of around 1,300,000 residents, which significantly decreased to 420,000 by 1945. The rapid population growth after the war led to a shortage of housing and land for new construction projects. To address this issue, the city authorities decided to expand the Warsaw area in 1951. Despite this expansion, they had to impose restrictions on residency registration, allowing only the spouses and children of permanent residents, as well as individuals of public importance, to register. This move resulted in a significant decrease in the population growth rate. Furthermore, it perpetuated the belief among Poles that Varsovians considered themselves better simply because they lived in the capital. Although these residency restrictions were lifted in 1990, this perception still lingers in Polish society, albeit to a lesser extent.

paragraphs.context: Warsaw, a multi-cultural city since its founding, had a diverse population in the early 20th century. The 1901 census reported 2.8% of residents as Protestants, 35.7% as Jews, 56.2% as Catholics, and a small percentage as Greek orthodox Christians. By 1909, the Jewish population had increased to 36.9%, while Protestants and Mariavites made up small percentages of the city's inhabitants. The religious diversity led to the construction of numerous places of worship across Warsaw, most of which were unfortunately destroyed during the events of the Warsaw Uprising in 1944. Despite efforts by the communist authorities to limit church construction after the war, a small number of religious buildings were eventually rebuilt.

paragraphs.context: In Poland, the smallest territorial division is called a commune or gmina. Cities are also considered communes, but they have a city charter. Both cities and communes are led by a mayor, referred to as a vogt (wójt) in communes and as a burmistrz in cities. Some larger cities, like Lublin, Kraków, Gdańsk, and Poznań, have the authority of counties or powiats, allowing them to carry out tasks like car registration, which is typically a powiat responsibility. In Warsaw, the districts, such as Wola and Ursynów, have some powiat privileges, like their own car registration systems. However, the districts in Kraków do not have powiat entitlements, so all vehicles in Kraków have the same type of registration numbers across all districts.

paragraphs.context: In the city of Warsaw, the legislative power is held by the Warsaw City Council, made up of 60 members. These members are elected directly by the citizens every four years. Similar to other legislative bodies, the City Council forms committees to oversee various aspects of city government. Any bills that are approved by a simple majority are then sent to the mayor, who is also the President of Warsaw, for final approval. If the mayor decides to veto a bill, the Council has a 30-day window to overturn the veto with a two-thirds majority vote.

Rephrased Context:
In Warsaw, the city official is known as the President. In Poland, this title is typically used for mayors of larger cities with a population over 100,000 or cities that had a president before 1990. The first President of Warsaw was Jan Andrzej Menich, serving from 1695 to 1696. From 1975 to 1990, the President of Warsaw also held the position of Warsaw Voivode. Since 1990, the President of Warsaw has been elected by the City council. From 1994 to 1999, the mayor of the Centrum district automatically became the President of Warsaw: the mayor of Centrum was selected by the district council of Centrum, which was made up solely of Centrum residents. Since 2002, the President of Warsaw is elected by all citizens of Warsaw.

paragraphs.context: Warsaw's city centre, Śródmieście, is a bustling hub for both national institutions and multinational companies. In 2006, the city was home to 304,016 registered companies, showcasing its growing business community on a global scale. By 2010, the total nominal GDP of Warsaw had reached 191.766 billion PLN, leading the region in foreign investment. paragraphs.context: The first stock exchange in Warsaw dates back to 1817, operating until World War II disrupted its activities. It was then revitalized in April 1991, after the fall of communist rule in Poland and the country's shift towards a free-market system. Today, the Warsaw Stock Exchange (WSE) stands out as the leading market in the region, boasting 374 listed companies and a total capitalization of 162,584 million EUR as of 31 August 2009. Interestingly, the stock exchange was temporarily housed in the former headquarters of the Polish United Workers' Party (PZPR) from 1991 to 2000.

paragraphs.context: In the 10th century and 11th centuries, the Normans, known as Norsemen, played a significant role in shaping the region of Normandy in France. Descended from Viking raiders from Denmark, Iceland, and Norway, they eventually pledged allegiance to King Charles III of West Francia under the leadership of Rollo. Over time, through intermarriage and cultural blending with the local populations, the Normans fused with the Carolingian-based cultures of West Francia. The unique cultural and ethnic identity of the Normans began to take shape in the early 10th century and continued to evolve in the centuries that followed.

Known for their military prowess and strong Catholic faith, they embraced Catholic orthodoxy as they settled in Frankish lands. Under the leadership of Richard I, the Duchy of Normandy became a powerful principality within medieval France. The Normans were not only skilled in military conquests, as seen in the Norman Conquest of England led by William the Conqueror, but also made important cultural contributions, such as their unique architecture and music. Their influence spread to regions like Sicily, Antioch, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, and even parts of Africa and the Canary Islands.

paragraphs.context: The term "Normans" in English is derived from the French words Normans/Normanz, the plural of Normant, which ultimately traces back to the Old Low Franconian term Nortmann meaning "Northman" or directly from Old Norse Norðmaðr. This Latinized term, recorded in Medieval Latin documents from the 9th century, was used to refer to Norseman and Viking alike.

paragraphs.context: During the 10th century, the Norse war bands, who were initially known for their destructive incursions into the rivers of France, eventually settled in the region with local women and personal property. The Duchy of Normandy was established in 911 through the treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte between King Charles III of West Francia and Rollo, a respected Viking ruler. This agreement granted Rollo and his warriors the lands between the Epte river and the Atlantic coast in exchange for protecting the region from further Viking attacks. The Duchy covered the northern part of present-day Upper Normandy, extending to the river Seine, and later expanded to the west beyond the Seine. This territory roughly corresponded to the ancient province of Rouen and followed the Roman administrative structure of Gallia Lugdunensis II.

paragraphs.context: Prior to Rollo's arrival, the population of Normandy was similar to that of Picardy and the Île-de-France, all of which were considered part of the "Frankish" region. Viking settlers had started to arrive in the 880s, settling in different areas such as Roumois and Pays de Caux in the east, as well as the Cotentin Peninsula in the west. These settlers were mainly divided by traditional regions, with little influx of foreign populations. Rollo's groups, who not only raided but also established settlements in Normandy and along the Atlantic coast, were a mix of Danes, Norwegians, Norse–Gaels, Orkney Vikings, possibly Swedes, and Anglo-Danes from the Danelaw region in England under Norse rule.

qas.question: Who upon arriving gave the original viking settlers a common identity?

paragraphs.context: Through the marriage of Rollo's Vikings and Frankish women, the Old Norse language and Norse religion were eventually replaced by Catholicism and the Gallo-Romance language of the local population in the north. This blending of maternal Frankish ancestry with Old Norse traditions resulted in the formation of a unique "Norman" culture in the region. The Norman language, a mix of Old Norse and the indigenous Romance language, was developed by the Norse ruling class and continues to be spoken in the area to this day.

paragraphs.context: Among the Norman families that made their mark in the Mediterranean, the descendants of Tancred of Hauteville and the Drengot family stood out. Rainulf Drengot was granted the county of Aversa in 1030 by Duke Sergius IV of Naples, marking the first Norman presence in the south. The Hauteville family elevated their status by declaring prince Guaimar IV of Salerno as the "Duke of Apulia and Calabria", leading to the appointment of William Iron Arm as count in the capital of Melfi. The Drengot family, on the other hand, rose to power in Capua. In 1047, emperor Henry III officially recognized the Hauteville leader, Drogo, with the title of "Duke and Master of Italy and Count of the Normans of all Apulia and Calabria".

paragraphs.context: Through strategic military campaigns, the Normans successfully overtook the territories of Sicily and Malta from the Saracens. This was achieved under the command of the renowned Robert Guiscard, a member of the Hauteville family, and his brother Roger the Great Count. Following in his father's footsteps, Roger II of Sicily was crowned king in 1130 by Antipope Anacletus II, marking a significant milestone in their rule. The Kingdom of Sicily thrived until 1194, when it was passed to the House of Hohenstaufen through a marriage alliance. The enduring legacy of the Normans can still be seen today in the form of majestic castles like William Iron Arm's fortress in Squillace and grand cathedrals such as Roger II's Cappella Palatina chapel in Palermo, each contributing to the region's rich architectural heritage.

paragraphs.context: In terms of governance, the Normans took inspiration from the administrative systems of the Byzantines, Arabs, and Lombards, while also incorporating their own feudal laws. This unique blend resulted in a government that promoted religious tolerance, with a meritocratic system in place that included individuals from Jewish, Muslim, and Christian backgrounds, both Catholic and Eastern Orthodox. The Kingdom of Sicily was a melting pot of Norman, Byzantine Greek, Arab, Lombard, and Sicilian cultures living together peacefully. The Norman rulers even had ambitions of expanding their territory to include Fatimid Egypt and the Crusader states in the Levant. One of the notable works from this era is the "Tabula Rogeriana", also known as "Kitab Rudjdjar" ("The Book of Roger"), a significant geographical treatise written by the Andalusian scholar al-Idrisi for King Roger II of Sicily.

paragraphs.context: In February 1082, Robert Guiscard, a Norman adventurer who had been made count of Apulia due to his military triumphs, successfully expelled the Byzantine forces from southern Italy. With the approval of Pope Gregory VII, Robert, acting as the Pope's vassal, expanded his campaign by conquering the Balkan peninsula to establish a presence for western feudal lords and the Catholic Church. By forming alliances with Croatia and the Catholic cities of Dalmatia, Robert led an army of 30,000 soldiers in 300 ships to the southern shores of Albania in 1081. They captured various towns and cities, such as Valona, Kanina, and Butrint, after a series of raids and battles. Despite these victories, local forces joined forces with the Byzantines against the Normans, leading to a betrayal of Dyrrachium to the Normans by Venetian and Amalfitan merchants in February 1082. This allowed the Norman forces to advance further inland, taking control of Ioannina and other cities in Macedonia and Thessaly before reaching Thessalonica. Internal disputes among the Norman leaders eventually led to their retreat back to Italy. However, they lost Dyrrachium, Valona, and Butrint in 1085 following Robert Guiscard's death.

paragraphs.context: Following the Norman invasion of Ireland at Bannow Bay in 1169, the Normans initially maintained a distinct culture and ethnicity. However, over time, they integrated into Irish society to the extent that they were often considered "more Irish than the Irish themselves." The Normans settled primarily in the east of Ireland, forming what later became known as the Pale, and constructed numerous impressive castles and settlements, including Trim Castle and Dublin Castle. The blending of Norman and Irish cultures led to a mutual exchange of language, customs, and perspectives. Many descendants of the Normans can be identified by their surnames, with names like French, (De) Roche, Devereux, D'Arcy, Treacy, and Lacy being particularly common in the southeast of Ireland, especially in southern County Wexford where the initial Norman settlements were concentrated. Additionally, names like Furlong are prevalent in these areas. Other Norman-Irish surnames, such as Morell (Murrell) derived from the French Norman name Morel, and those beginning with Fitz (meaning son in Norman), like Fitzgerald, FitzGibbons (Gibbons), Fitzmaurice, Barry (de Barra), and De Búrca (Burke), also indicate Norman lineage.

Electrical Engineer:

In 1893, at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, George Westinghouse successfully showcased the superiority of alternating current over direct current, winning the bid to light the fairgrounds. paragraphs.context: In 1900, Nikola Tesla was granted patents for a "system of transmitting electrical energy" and "an electrical transmitter." When Guglielmo Marconi successfully completed the first transatlantic radio transmission in 1901, Tesla humorously remarked that it was achieved using 17 Tesla patents, although there is little evidence to support this assertion. This event marked the beginning of a series of patent disputes over radio technology, with Tesla's patents being initially upheld in 1903 but then reversed in favor of Marconi in 1904. It wasn't until 1943, when the Supreme Court of the United States made a decision to restore the prior patents of Tesla, Oliver Lodge, and John Stone. The court clarified that their ruling did not diminish Marconi's claim as the pioneer of radio transmission but rather highlighted the uncertainty surrounding Marconi's patents, preventing him from claiming infringement on those same patents (rumors suggest that the high court aimed to negate a World War I claim against the U.S. government by the Marconi Company by simply reinstating Tesla's prior patent).

In this case, the instance would be a specific number, like 15, and the solution would be either "yes" if the number is prime or "no" if it's not (in this instance, the solution would be "no"). paragraphs.context: Decision problems are a fundamental concept in computational complexity theory that we're currently learning about in class. Basically, a decision problem is a type of computational problem where the answer is either yes or no, or in other words, either 1 or 0. In simpler terms, it's like a yes or no question. You can think of a decision problem as a formal language, where the instances that result in a yes answer are part of the language, and those that result in a no answer are not. Our goal is to use an algorithm to determine if a given input string belongs to the formal language or not. If the algorithm gives a yes as the answer, it means it accepts the input string, but if it's a no, then it rejects the input.

paragraphs.context: In computer science, a Turing machine serves as a theoretical concept of a general computing machine. This machine operates by manipulating symbols on a strip of tape. Though not meant for practical use, Turing machines are valuable in illustrating various computing scenarios, ranging from high-tech supercomputers to simple mathematicians with pen and paper. According to the Church-Turing thesis, if a problem can be solved with an algorithm, there is a corresponding Turing machine capable of solving it. Additionally, it's been established that any computation possible on other known models, like RAM machines, Conway's Game of Life, or various programming languages, can be achieved with a Turing machine. paragraphs.context: In computer science, when we talk about solving problems within a specific amount of time and space, we often refer to computational models like the deterministic Turing machine. The time taken by a deterministic Turing machine M to solve a problem is actually the total number of state transitions, or steps, it makes before giving an answer – which can be either "yes" or "no". We say that a Turing machine operates within time f(n) if it takes at most f(n) steps to solve a problem of length n. If a decision problem can be solved within a time frame f(n), then there exists a Turing machine that operates within that time frame to solve it. Complexity theory categorizes problems based on their level of difficulty, with a set of problems solvable within time f(n) denoted by DTIME(f(n)).

paragraphs.context: In the analysis of algorithms, it is crucial to establish both upper and lower bounds on the computation time needed by the most efficient algorithm to solve a specific problem. When proving an upper bound T(n) on time complexity, it is sufficient to demonstrate the existence of an algorithm with a runtime of at most T(n). Conversely, proving lower bounds is a challenging task as it necessitates making a statement about every conceivable algorithm capable of solving the problem. This includes algorithms that may not yet be developed. To establish a lower bound of T(n) for a problem, one must show that no algorithm can outperform a time complexity lower than T(n).

If we allow for polynomial variations in the running time, the Cobham-Edmonds thesis suggests that the time complexities between two general models of computation are related polynomially. This concept is fundamental to the complexity class P, which consists of decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. paragraphs.context: In computer science, we often use reductions to define complexity classes. A reduction is basically just a way to transform one problem into another. It helps us understand when one problem is at least as difficult as another. For example, if we can solve problem X by using an algorithm for problem Y, then X is not harder than Y, and we say that X reduces to Y. There are different kinds of reductions, like Cook reductions, Karp reductions, and Levin reductions, based on how they work. We also consider the complexity of reductions, like whether they can be done in polynomial time or log space.

qas.question: According to reduction, if X and Y can be solved by the same algorithm then X performs what function in relationship to Y?

paragraphs.context: In computer science, we often use polynomial-time reduction to simplify problems. This means that the process of reducing a problem to a simpler form takes polynomial time. For instance, when we need to square an integer, we can actually break it down to the simpler task of multiplying two integers. This implies that an algorithm designed for multiplying two integers can also be used for squaring an integer. It's as simple as feeding the same input to both integer inputs of the multiplication algorithm. Therefore, we can conclude that squaring is no more challenging than multiplication, as squaring can be reduced to simply multiplying two integers.

paragraphs.context: Understanding the concept of a problem being considered hard for a complexity class is crucial in our study of complexity theory. A problem X is deemed hard for a class of problems C if every problem in C can be transformed or reduced to X. This essentially means that X is the most challenging problem in C, as having an algorithm for X enables us to tackle any problem within C. It's important to note that the difficulty of problems varies based on the specific type of reduction being employed. For complexity classes beyond P, polynomial-time reductions are commonly utilized. For instance, the collection of problems that pose a significant challenge for NP falls under the category of NP-hard problems.

paragraphs.context: In computer science, if a problem X is considered to be complete for a class C, it means that X is the toughest problem within C. The class of NP-complete problems consists of the most challenging issues in NP, meaning that they are the least likely to have a solution in P. If we could reduce a known NP-complete problem, Π2, to another problem, Π1, it would mean that there is no known polynomial-time solution for Π1. This is because a polynomial-time solution for Π1 would also provide a polynomial-time solution for Π2. Moreover, if we were to find an NP-complete problem that could be solved in polynomial time, it would imply that P = NP, which is a problem that has not been resolved yet.

qas.question: The hardest problems in NP can be analogously written as what class of problems?

paragraphs.context: In the world of computer science, we often talk about the complexity class P as a way to represent tasks that can be efficiently solved with an algorithm. This idea is known as the Cobham-Edmonds thesis. On the other hand, the complexity class NP includes problems like the Boolean satisfiability problem, Hamiltonian path problem, and vertex cover problem that we would like to solve efficiently, but don't have efficient algorithms for. It's important to note that because deterministic Turing machines are a special case of non-deterministic Turing machines, any problem in P is also considered a member of the class NP.

What complexity class is commonly characterized by unknown algorithms to enhance solvability?

paragraphs.context: As a computer science researcher, I understand the significance of the question surrounding whether P equals NP. Finding a solution could lead to more efficient solutions for many important problems across various fields, such as integer programming in operations research, logistics, and protein structure prediction in biology. The resolution of the P versus NP problem is so significant that there is a US$1,000,000 prize available for anyone who can provide a solution.

What is the prize offered for finding a solution to P=NP?

paragraphs.context: Ladner proved that if P is not equal to NP, there are certain problems within NP that are not in P or NP-complete, known as NP-intermediate problems. Among these NP-intermediate problems are the graph isomorphism problem, the discrete logarithm problem, and the integer factorization problem, which are believed to fall into this category. These problems are some of the rare NP problems that have not yet been classified as either in P or NP-complete.

qas.question: Who demonstrated that P= NP implies problems not present in P or NP-complete?

paragraphs.context: The graph isomorphism problem, as studied by researchers like Babai and Luks, investigates whether two given finite graphs can be considered identical. In the world of complexity theory, there is a lingering question about whether this problem falls under P, is NP-complete, or something in between. While the actual classification remains unknown, many theorists lean towards the notion that it is not NP-complete. If it were found to be NP-complete, this would have significant implications as the polynomial time hierarchy would compress to its second level, which contradicts the commonly held belief that the hierarchy extends infinitely. Fortunately, current algorithms developed by Babai and Luks demonstrate an impressive runtime of 2O(√(n log(n))) for graphs containing n vertices.

qas.question: What is the problem attributed to defining if two finite graphs are isomorphic?
What class is most commonly not ascribed to the graph isomorphism problem in spite of definitive determination?

To what level would the polynomial time hierarchy collapse if graph isomorphism is NP-complete?

paragraphs.context: The integer factorization problem, which involves finding the prime factors of a given integer, is a crucial challenge in modern cryptographic systems like RSA. Despite extensive research, no efficient algorithm has been discovered for integer factorization, with the general number field sieve being the most effective method to date. This algorithm has a time complexity of O(e(64/9)1/3(n.log 2)1/3(log (n.log 2))2/3) for factoring an n-bit integer. While Shor's quantum algorithm offers a polynomial-time solution, its implications for non-quantum complexity classes remain unclear.

qas.question: What computational problem is commonly associated with prime factorization?

paragraphs.context: In the field of computer science, there is a strong belief that many of the complexity classes we study are not equal to each other, although this has yet to be definitively proven. For example, we often arrange these classes in a hierarchy like P ⊆ NP ⊆ PP ⊆ PSPACE, suggesting that they are distinct. If P is proven to be not equal to NP, then it follows that P is also not equal to PSPACE. Given that there are numerous complexity classes positioned between P and PSPACE, such as RP, BPP, PP, BQP, MA, PH, and more, it is conceivable that they could all ultimately converge into a single class. The discovery that any of these classes are unequal would represent a significant advancement in our understanding of complexity theory.

qas.question: What is an expression that can be used to illustrate the suspected inequality of complexity classes?

paragraphs.context: In the field of computer science, problems that can technically be solved but would take an impractical amount of time are referred to as intractable problems. These are typically problems that do not have solutions that can be found in polynomial time, making them extremely time-consuming even for small inputs. According to the Cobham-Edmonds thesis, only problems that can be solved in polynomial time are realistically computable on a standard computational device. Intractable problems include those that are EXPTIME-hard and, if NP is not equal to P, then NP-complete problems are also considered intractable. For example, if a program performs 2^n operations before finishing, and a computer can do 10^12 operations per second, running the program for n=100 would take about 4 x 10^10 years, a time frame comparable to the age of the universe. This illustrates why exponential-time algorithms can be impractical for real-world applications, regardless of technological advancements. Even polynomial-time algorithms with high exponents, like n^15, may not be efficient in practice and are only useful for small inputs.

qas.question: Problems capable of theoretical solutions but consuming unreasonable time in practical application are known as what?

paragraphs.context: The concept of intractability can be interpreted differently in real-world scenarios. Just because a problem is not within the class P doesn't necessarily mean that solving large instances of the problem is always difficult. For instance, while the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic falls outside of P, there are existing algorithms that can efficiently solve it in most cases. Similarly, algorithms have been developed to handle the NP-complete knapsack problem efficiently for a wide range of sizes, and SAT solvers are capable of managing large instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem in less than quadratic time.

In June 1521, Wittenberg experienced some unrest as Andreas Karlstadt and Gabriel Zwilling, former Augustinian friars, initiated radical reforms that went beyond what Luther had envisioned. These reforms led to disturbances, including a rebellion by the Augustinian friars, destruction of religious statues and images, and criticism of the town council. Luther, who was kept informed of these developments while staying at Wartburg, decided to visit Wittenberg in early December 1521. Following his visit, Luther wrote a plea to Christians to avoid insurrection and rebellion. The situation in Wittenberg worsened after Christmas when a group of radical preachers known as the Zwickau prophets arrived to spread ideas like human equality, adult baptism, and the imminent return of Christ. In light of these developments, when the town council requested Luther's return, he felt compelled to intervene.

paragraphs.context: Despite his successful reform efforts in Wittenberg, Luther was not able to prevent the spread of radical ideas in other regions. Influential preachers like Nicholas Storch and Thomas Müntzer played a key role in sparking the German Peasants' War of 1524–25, which resulted in numerous violent acts, often carried out in Luther's name. Peasant uprisings had been occurring on a smaller scale since the 15th century. Luther's writings criticizing the Church and the social hierarchy, sometimes using progressive language, caused many peasants to believe that he would support a general uprising against the ruling classes. Rebellions erupted in Franconia, Swabia, and Thuringia in 1524, receiving backing from discontented nobles, many of whom were financially struggling. With leaders like Müntzer in Thuringia and Michael Gaismair in Tyrol, the rebellions evolved into a full-blown war.

paragraphs.context: As a Christian theologian, I condemned the rebels based on three main reasons. Firstly, by opting for violence instead of submitting to the secular authorities as advised by Christ, they were disregarding the teachings to "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's". St. Paul's letter to the Romans highlighted that all rulers are appointed by God and should not be opposed. This principle formed the basis for the belief in the Divine Right of Kings or, in the case of Germany, the divine right of the princes. Secondly, the rebels' violent actions of rebellion, robbery, and looting placed them outside both the laws of God and the Empire, warranting punishment "in body and soul" as criminals and murderers. paragraphs.context: In order to avoid causing confusion or unrest among the people, Martin Luther chose not to make extreme changes. Instead, he focused on the church in the Electorate of Saxony and acted as an adviser to churches in new territories. He collaborated closely with the new elector, John the Steadfast, seeking his guidance and financial assistance for a church that had lost much of its assets and income following the split from Rome. According to Luther's biographer Martin Brecht, this partnership marked the beginning of a controversial shift towards a church government under the temporal sovereign. The elector authorized a church visitation, a duty previously held by bishops. Luther's practical reforms sometimes did not align with his initial radical views. For instance, the Instructions for the Visitors of Parish Pastors in Electoral Saxony (1528) emphasized the importance of repentance in the forgiveness of sins, despite Luther's belief that faith alone brings justification. Johannes Agricola, a reformer from Eisleben, disputed this compromise, leading Luther to rebuke him for preaching that faith is separate from works. The Instruction presents a challenge for those trying to track a consistent progression in Luther's beliefs and actions.

paragraphs.context: In response to the requests for a German liturgy from the members of my congregation, I, Martin, wrote a German Mass and published it in early 1526. I didn't see it as a replacement for my earlier adaptation of the Latin Mass from 1523 but rather as an option for the "simple people", as a way to encourage them to believe and embrace Christianity. I based my order on the Catholic service but removed "everything that smacks of sacrifice", allowing everyone to receive both the wine and bread during the celebration. I kept elements like the elevation of the host and chalice but made things like Mass vestments and candles optional, giving freedom in the way ceremonies were conducted. Some reformers thought my service was too similar to Catholic practices, but I believed it was a way to connect with the common people. My goal was to make the Mass more accessible, so I included hymns and parts of the liturgy in German for everyone to participate in, including my unison setting of the Creed. To educate the simple people and the youth, I added religious instruction into the weekday services through the catechism, as well as simplified versions of baptism and marriage ceremonies.

paragraphs.context: In 1523, Martin Luther wrote "Aus tiefer Not schrei ich zu dir" ("From depths of woe I cry to you") as a hymnic adaptation of Psalm 130. He wanted to inspire his fellow evangelical colleagues to follow suit and write psalm-hymns for German worship. Collaborating with Paul Speratus, Luther's hymn, along with seven others, were published in the Achtliederbuch, marking the first Lutheran hymnal. The hymn was further developed in 1524 by Luther and Speratus to emphasize the theme of "grace alone", reflecting essential Reformation doctrine. This expanded version of "Aus tiefer Not" became a regular feature in regional Lutheran liturgies and was commonly used at funerals, including Luther's own. Additionally, Luther's hymn, along with Erhart Hegenwalt's adaptation of Psalm 51, were incorporated into the fifth part of Luther's catechism, focusing on confession.

paragraphs.context: In the early part of 1537, Johannes Agricola, who was currently serving as a pastor in the town where Martin Luther was born, delivered a sermon proclaiming that it was through God's gospel, not the moral law outlined in the Ten Commandments, that Christians could discern God's wrath. paragraphs.context: From December 1539, Luther was drawn into a situation involving the bigamy of Philip I, Landgrave of Hesse, who expressed a desire to marry one of the ladies-in-waiting of his wife. Seeking approval, Philip consulted Luther, Melanchthon, and Bucer, using the polygamy of patriarchs as a precedent. The theologians refrained from giving a definitive ruling and reluctantly advised the landgrave that if he insisted on pursuing the marriage, he should do so discreetly. Consequently, on 4 March 1540, Philip married a second wife, Margarethe von der Saale, with Melanchthon and Bucer as witnesses. However, the marriage was unable to be kept under wraps, and Philip threatened to expose Luther's involvement. Luther advised him to deny the marriage completely, resulting in Philip following through during the subsequent public controversy. According to Luther's biographer Martin Brecht, the guidance given to Philip of Hesse was considered one of Luther's gravest errors, with Luther bearing significant responsibility alongside the landgrave. The historical narrative primarily attributes accountability to Luther. Brecht argues that the error was not in providing private pastoral counsel, but rather in underestimating the political repercussions. The episode led to enduring harm to Luther's reputation.

paragraphs.context: Throughout his career, Luther wrote about the Jews, although only a few of his works directly addressed them. Despite rarely coming into contact with Jews in his own life, his views were influenced by a theological and cultural background that viewed Jews as a people who had expelled Jews some ninety years prior and were responsible for the murder of Christ. Luther believed that the Jews were blasphemers and dishonest because they did not accept the divinity of Jesus, a belief that Christians held dear. He also recognized that all individuals who opposed God were equally at fault. In 1516, Luther highlighted the hypocrisy of those who insulted Jews, while failing to acknowledge their own faults in the eyes of God. In 1523, he advocated for kindness towards Jews in his work "That Jesus Christ was Born a Jew" and aimed to convert them to Christianity. However, when his attempts at conversion proved unsuccessful, his attitude towards Jews became increasingly resentful. In his 2010 book on Bonhoeffer, Christian author Eric Metaxas argued that Luther's negative views towards Jews intensified as his health declined.

JKL secured the rights to broadcast highlights of most matches, while GHI's £304m offer would grant them exclusive rights to air up to 60 live matches per year starting in 1992. paragraphs.context: In November 2006, the Victorian Legislative Council elections underwent significant changes, transitioning to a multi-member proportional representation system. The State of Victoria was reorganized into eight electorates, each represented by five officials elected through the Single Transferable Vote method. The total number of upper house members was reduced from 44 to 40, and their term of office now aligns with the lower house at four years. Elections for the Victorian Parliament are now held in November every four years, bringing stability and regularity to the political cycle. Prior to these reforms, the Legislative Council had 44 members elected from 22 two-member electorates to serve eight-year terms.

paragraphs.context: Before British colonization, the region now known as Victoria was home to a diverse group of Indigenous peoples, collectively referred to as the Koori. In 1788, Great Britain claimed the area as part of the colony of New South Wales. The first European settlement was established in 1803 at Sullivan Bay. By 1836, much of present-day Victoria was included in the Port Phillip District, an administrative division of New South Wales. Victoria officially became a separate colony in 1851 and gained self-government in 1855. The discovery of gold in the 1850s and 1860s led to a significant increase in population and wealth. By the time Australia federated in 1901, Melbourne had emerged as the largest city and primary financial hub in the region. paragraphs.context: In 1700, a group of French Huguenots made their way to Virginia from England, enticed by the promise of land grants in Lower Norfolk County. Their descendants dispersed westward into the Piedmont region and beyond, settling in states like Kentucky, Tennessee, and Missouri. paragraphs.context: New Rochelle, situated in Westchester County along the northern coastline of Long Island Sound, holds significance as the landing spot for the Huguenots in New York. The Huguenots arrived at "Bauffet's Point" on Davenports Neck after fleeing religious persecution in England, just before the Edict of Nantes was revoked. With the assistance of Jacob Leisler, they acquired a six thousand one hundred acre tract of land from John Pell, the Lord of Pelham Manor. The town was named New Rochelle in homage to their former stronghold in France, La Rochelle. Initially, a wooden church was constructed, followed by a sturdier stone building. Before the stone church was built, dedicated congregants would trek the twenty-three mile distance from New Rochelle to New York City for Sunday service. The stone church was later replaced by Trinity-St. Paul's Episcopal Church, which houses historical artifacts such as the original bell from the French Huguenot Church "Eglise du St. Esperit" in New York City. The church also features a tower room where the relic is preserved. The Huguenot cemetery, known as "Huguenot Burial Ground", is a revered historic site that serves as the final resting place for many of New Rochelle's founders, early settlers, and influential citizens spanning over three centuries.

paragraphs.context: The atmospheric engine, created by Thomas Newcomen around 1712, was the first commercially successful true engine capable of generating and transmitting power to a machine. Building upon Papin's piston proposal and improving upon Savery's steam pump, Newcomen's engine was primarily used for pumping water due to its relative inefficiency. By utilizing steam to create a partial vacuum under a piston in a cylinder, the engine was able to drain mine workings at previously unreachable depths and provided a sustainable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories located far from suitable sources. The water used in powering the wheel was then pumped back up into a reservoir above the wheel for reuse.

paragraphs.context: In the 1840s and 50s, engineers experimented with different patent valve gears, such as Corliss and Joy, to improve the efficiency of steam engines. These gears had a separate expansion valve that could be adjusted, along with the main slide valve. While this setup allowed for better control of events like cutoff, it also increased friction and wear on the components. To address this issue, engineers started lengthening the rubbing surfaces of the valve to create an overlap on the admission side, keeping the exhaust side open for a longer period after cutoff. This solution, though somewhat complex, was effective in improving engine performance and paved the way for simpler valve motions like Stephenson, Joy, and Walschaerts. However, the more advanced poppet valve gears, like the Corliss design, with separate admission and exhaust valves driven by trip mechanisms, faced challenges in terms of leakage and reliability outside of stationary applications.

paragraphs.context: Lead fusible plugs are typically found in the crown of a boiler's firebox. paragraphs.context: In 1804, the British engineer Arthur Woolf came up with a way to reduce the heating and cooling effects in steam engines by introducing his Woolf high-pressure compound engine. This innovative design involved the expansion of high-pressure steam in a high-pressure cylinder before moving into lower-pressure cylinders. This division of expansion across multiple cylinders helped minimize heat loss and increase engine efficiency. By spreading out the steam expansion, torque variability was decreased. To extract the same amount of work from lower-pressure steam, larger cylinder volumes were needed due to the increased steam volume. This led to larger bore and stroke measurements in the low-pressure cylinders, resulting in overall larger cylinders.

paragraphs.context: In the past, the efficiency of a steam engine was measured by its "duty". This concept was introduced by Watt to show the improvement in efficiency of his engines compared to previous designs by Newcomen. Duty is calculated as the number of foot-pounds of work produced by burning one bushel (94 pounds) of coal. The most efficient Newcomen designs had a duty of around 7 million, with the majority falling closer to 5 million. Watt's initial low-pressure designs had a duty as high as 25 million, but typically averaged around 17, representing a significant improvement compared to the average Newcomen design. The introduction of high-pressure steam in early Watt engines further increased the duty to 65 million, showcasing continued advancements in steam engine efficiency.

paragraphs.context: In 1698, Thomas Savery created the first commercial steam-powered water pump. By utilizing condensing steam to generate a vacuum, the pump successfully lifted water from below and then used steam pressure to raise it even higher. Although small engines worked well, larger models faced challenges such as limited lift height and the risk of boiler explosions. Despite these drawbacks, the Savery engine found applications in mines, pumping stations, and water wheels for textile machinery. Notably, Bento de Moura Portugal made improvements to Savery's design, as noted by John Smeaton in a publication from 1751. This updated version made the engine self-operating and was in use until the late 18th century, with reports of one remaining functional engine as late as 1820.

paragraphs.context: In power plants without combined heat and power systems, steam turbines utilize surface condensers to dissipate heat. These condensers are typically cooled by water sourced from oceans, rivers, lakes, and sometimes by dry cooling towers, which use evaporation to cool without excessive water consumption. In locations where water is costly, dry type cooling towers, similar to automobile radiators, are preferred. These evaporative cooling towers utilize rejected heat to evaporate water, separating it from the condensate that recirculates in a closed loop back to the boiler. They are distinguishable by visible plumes caused by condensed evaporated water rising with warm air. Compared to the use of river or lake water for cooling, evaporative cooling towers require significantly less water; for instance, a 700 megawatt coal-fired power plant may only need about 3600 cubic meters of makeup water per hour.

paragraphs.context: In a steam turbine, there are rotating discs called rotors mounted on a drive shaft, which alternate with static discs known as stators fixed to the turbine casing. The rotors have blades at the outer edge that steam acts upon, creating rotary motion. The stators have fixed blades that redirect the steam flow to the next rotor stage. A steam turbine typically exhausts into a surface condenser to provide a vacuum. The stages of the turbine are designed to extract the maximum work from a specific velocity and pressure of steam, resulting in high- and low-pressure stages. To maintain efficiency, turbines need to rotate at high speeds, usually around 3600 revolutions per minute in the USA and 3000 RPM in Europe. In nuclear power applications, the speeds are typically halved. Turbines can only provide power when rotating in one direction, requiring a reversing stage or gearbox for applications needing power in the opposite direction.

paragraphs.context: Steam engines are equipped with two safety mechanisms to prevent boiler pressure from getting too high. Adjustments made by engine drivers sometimes led to accidents, as they would tighten the valve to increase steam pressure and power from the engine. Modern safety valves use an adjustable spring-loaded valve that is secured with a seal to prevent unauthorized adjustments. This design provides a higher level of safety in steam engine operations.

paragraphs.context: The Rankine cycle is often called a practical Carnot cycle because, with the use of an efficient turbine, the TS diagram begins to resemble the Carnot cycle. The key distinction is that heat addition (in the boiler) and rejection (in the condenser) are processes at constant pressure in the Rankine cycle, whereas they are processes at constant temperature in the theoretical Carnot cycle. During this cycle, a pump is utilized to pressurize the working fluid received as a liquid from the condenser, rather than as a gas. This approach of pumping the working fluid in liquid form during the cycle requires less energy compared to compressing the working fluid in gaseous form using a compressor (as in the Carnot cycle). The operation of a reciprocating steam engine deviates from that of turbines due to condensation and re-evaporation happening in the cylinder or steam inlet passages.

paragraphs.context: In the past, people believed that materials like wood and coal contained a lot of phlogiston, while substances like iron had very little. They noticed that when things burned, they appeared to become lighter and seem to lose something. However, they didn't consider the role of air or conduct any experiments to test this theory. It was later discovered that materials like wood actually become lighter because of the gases produced during combustion. paragraphs.context: In a molecule of dioxygen, the two oxygen atoms are bonded to each other. This bond can be explained as a covalent double bond that is formed when molecular orbitals created from the atomic orbitals of the individual oxygen atoms are filled, resulting in a bond order of two. Specifically, the double bond is the outcome of filling orbitals in a low-to-high energy sequence, known as Aufbau, where contributions from the 2s electrons are canceled after the σ and σ* orbitals are filled. This involves overlap of the two atomic 2p orbitals along the O-O molecular axis (σ) and the overlap of two pairs of atomic 2p orbitals perpendicular to the O-O molecular axis (π), followed by the cancellation of contributions from the remaining two of the six 2p electrons after they partially fill the lowest π and π* orbitals.

qas.question: What is the bond order of dioxygen molecules?

paragraphs.context: In the late 18th century, the element oxygen was independently discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Joseph Priestley in 1773 or earlier and 1774, respectively. However, Priestley is often credited with priority as his work was published first. The term "oxygen" was later coined by Antoine Lavoisier in 1777, after conducting experiments that disproved the phlogiston theory of combustion and corrosion. This element received its name from the Greek roots meaning "acid producer", due to the misconception at the time that all acids contained oxygen. Oxygen has since proven to be crucial in various industrial applications such as steel production, welding, rocket propellant, as well as in life support systems in aircraft, submarines, and spaceflight.

Dioxygen, also known as O2, is the most common allotrope of elemental oxygen found on Earth. With a bond length of 121 pm and a bond energy of 498 kJ·mol−1, it plays a major role in the Earth's atmosphere. paragraphs.context: In the real world, we can observe that oxygen dissolves more easily in water than nitrogen does. When water is in equilibrium with air, we find that for every 1 molecule of dissolved O2, there are about 2 molecules of N2, whereas in the atmosphere, the ratio is closer to 1:4. The amount of oxygen that can dissolve in water is affected by temperature, with approximately twice as much (14.6 mg·L−1) dissolving at 0 °C compared to 20 °C (7.6 mg·L−1). At the standard conditions of 25 °C and 1 atmosphere of air pressure, freshwater contains around 6.04 milliliters of oxygen per liter, while seawater contains about 4.95 mL per liter. If we lower the temperature to 5 °C, the solubility of oxygen increases to 9.0 mL per liter for water (50% more than at 25 °C) and 7.2 mL per liter for seawater (45% more than at 25 °C).

paragraphs.context: In the late 19th century, scientists discovered that air could be turned into liquid form and its different components separated by compressing and cooling it. Using a cascade method, Swiss chemist and physicist Raoul Pierre Pictet successfully evaporated liquid sulfur dioxide to liquefy carbon dioxide, which was then used to cool oxygen gas to the point of liquefaction. Pictet's telegram to the French Academy of Sciences in Paris on December 22, 1877, announced the groundbreaking discovery of liquid oxygen. Just two days later, French physicist Louis Paul Cailletet also revealed his own technique for liquefying molecular oxygen. However, due to the small quantities produced in each experiment, only a few drops of the liquid were obtained, preventing any significant analysis. It wasn't until March 29, 1883, that Polish scientists Zygmunt Wróblewski and Karol Olszewski were able to successfully stabilize liquid oxygen for the first time.

paragraphs.context: As a planetary science researcher, I have studied the oxygen isotopes in samples collected from the Earth, the Moon, Mars, and meteorites. paragraphs.context: Prior to the evolution of photosynthetic archaea and bacteria around 3.5 billion years ago, the Earth's atmosphere had little to no free oxygen. The oxygen produced by these organisms initially reacted with iron in the oceans, creating banded iron formations for about 1 billion years. This process continued until around 1.7 billion years ago, when free oxygen levels reached approximately 10% of what they are today.

paragraphs.context: In the field of chemistry, the production of oxygen gas can be achieved through the electrolysis of water, leading to the creation of molecular oxygen and hydrogen. It is essential to use DC electricity for this process; if AC is utilized instead, the gases produced may be explosive due to the 2:1 ratio of hydrogen and oxygen. Despite common misconceptions, the 2:1 ratio observed during DC electrolysis of acidified water does not definitively prove the empirical formula of water as H2O, unless certain assumptions are made about the molecular formulae of hydrogen and oxygen themselves. Another technique involves the electrocatalytic O2 evolution from oxides and oxoacids. Chemical catalysts, such as those found in chemical oxygen generators or oxygen candles used for life-support equipment on submarines and commercial airliners during depressurization emergencies, can also aid in the production of oxygen. An additional method of air separation technology includes forcing air to dissolve through ceramic membranes based on zirconium dioxide, either through high pressure or an electric current, in order to obtain nearly pure O2 gas.

paragraphs.context: In hyperbaric (high-pressure) medicine, special oxygen chambers are utilized to raise the partial pressure of O2 around both patients and medical staff. These chambers are effective in treating conditions such as carbon monoxide poisoning, gas gangrene, and decompression sickness (the 'bends'). By increasing the O2 concentration in the lungs, carbon monoxide is displaced from the heme group of hemoglobin. Furthermore, the elevated partial pressure of oxygen helps eliminate anaerobic bacteria that cause gas gangrene. Decompression sickness, which occurs in divers who decompress too rapidly after a dive, leads to the formation of bubbles of inert gas, mostly nitrogen and helium, in their blood. paragraphs.context: In Maxime Faget's initial design for the Apollo spacecraft, a cone-shaped command module was combined with one of several service modules to provide propulsion and electrical power. The spacecraft was sized appropriately for missions to the space station, cis-lunar space, and lunar landings. As President Kennedy's goal of a Moon landing became official, detailed work began on the Command/Service Module (CSM). This module would house the crew for the entire direct-ascent mission and also serve as the vessel for lifting off from the lunar surface to return home. The final decision to use lunar orbit rendezvous altered the CSM's role to that of a translunar ferry, transporting the crew along with a new spacecraft, the Lunar Excursion Module (LEM). The LEM, later shortened to Lunar Module (LM), would be responsible for taking two men to the lunar surface and then returning them to the CSM.

paragraphs.context: The Command Module (CM) was specifically designed to carry a team of three astronauts safely from launch to lunar orbit and then back to Earth, where it would land in an ocean. Additionally, the CM was equipped with parachutes to slow its descent for a smooth splashdown. paragraphs.context: The Lunar Module (LM) had the purpose of safely transporting two astronauts from lunar orbit to the Moon's surface and back to the Command Module in orbit. The LM, weighing 15,100 kg, was not intended for Earth's atmospheric entry or return. Its lightweight fuselage was built without aerodynamic considerations, housing separate descent and ascent stages with their own engines. The descent stage stored propellant, consumables, and exploration gear, while the ascent stage held the crew cabin, propellant, and control system. The base LM model supported stays on the surface for up to 34 hours, while an Extended Lunar Module, weighing 16,400 kg, extended surface stays to over 3 days.

The decision on June 11, 1962, to switch to lunar orbit rendezvous instead of direct ascent paved the way for the Saturn V to replace the Nova, allowing for the successful development and launch of the Apollo missions.

paragraphs.context: As an aerospace engineer, I worked on the Saturn IB, an upgraded version of the Saturn I. The S-IB first stage provided 1,600,000 pounds-force (7,120 kN) of thrust, while the second stage featured the S-IVB-200 with a single J-2 engine generating 200,000 lbf (890 kN) of thrust using liquid hydrogen fuel with LOX. The third stage utilized a restartable version of the S-IVB. With the Saturn IB, we could launch payloads of over 40,000 pounds (18,100 kg) into low Earth orbit, making it suitable for carrying a partially fueled CSM or the LM. The AS-200 series designation was used for Saturn IB launch vehicles and flights, with "AS" representing "Apollo Saturn" and the "2" indicating it was the third member of the Saturn rocket family.

paragraphs.context: As an aerospace engineer, our team designed the three-stage Saturn V to transport a fully fueled CSM and LM to the Moon. Measuring 33 feet (10.1 m) in diameter and towering at 363 feet (110.6 m) with a 96,800-pound (43,900 kg) lunar payload, we later upgraded its capability to accommodate 103,600 pounds (47,000 kg) for advanced lunar missions. The S-IC first stage burned RP-1/LOX, delivering a rated thrust of 7,500,000 pounds-force (33,400 kN), which was later increased to 7,610,000 pounds-force (33,900 kN). The second and third stages utilized liquid hydrogen, with the third stage, a modified version of the S-IVB, boasting increased thrust to 230,000 lbf (1,020 kN) and the ability to restart the engine for translunar injection after reaching a parking orbit.

paragraphs.context: In order to address the fire hazards, our team implemented several changes to the Block II spacecraft and operational procedures. This included switching to a nitrogen/oxygen mixture instead of pure oxygen for pre-launch and during launch, as well as eliminating flammable cabin and space suit materials. The Block II design already included a quick-release, outward opening door to replace the flammable Block I plug-type hatch cover. The manned Block I program was terminated, with Block I spacecraft only being used for unmanned Saturn V flights. Crew members will now wear the updated, fire-resistant Block II space suits for added safety, with all designations following the Block II protocol, regardless of the presence of a LM on the mission.

paragraphs.context: In April 1970, Apollo was grounded after the liquid oxygen tank exploded, disabling the Service Module during the Apollo 13 mission with astronauts Jim Lovell, Jack Swigert, and Fred Haise. The crew had to rely on the Lunar Module as a "life boat" to safely return to Earth. Following a review, it was found that the tank had been damaged in the factory and a subcontractor had not followed the updated design specifications for a tank component. As a result, Apollo missions were put on hold for the remainder of 1970 while the oxygen tank was redesigned and an additional one was added. paragraphs.context: The anorthosite rocks collected from the Moon during the Apollo Program are incredibly old, with ages ranging from about 3.2 billion years for basaltic samples from the lunar maria to approximately 4.6 billion years for samples from the highlands crust. These samples provide valuable insights into the early stages of the Solar System's formation, a period that is not well represented on Earth. One particularly significant rock, known as the Genesis Rock, was brought back by astronauts David Scott and James Irwin during the Apollo 15 mission. This rock is predominantly made up of the calcium-rich feldspar mineral anorthite and is thought to be a key component of the highland crust. The discovery of the geochemical component KREEP, which has no known equivalent on Earth, along with the anorthositic samples, suggests that the outer layer of the Moon was once entirely molten, supporting the concept of a lunar magma ocean.

qas.question: What was the name of the rock found during the Apollo 15 mission that KREEP was discovered in?

paragraphs.context: As a lunar geologist studying the returned samples from the Moon, I have noticed that almost all the rocks exhibit evidence of impact process effects. Many of the samples show micrometeoroid impact craters, a phenomenon rarely seen on Earth rocks due to our thick atmosphere. Additionally, there are clear signs of high pressure shock waves that occurred during impact events. Some of the samples even appear to be impact melt, indicating materials melted near an impact crater. Overall, the rocks are highly brecciated, showcasing the multiple impact events they have been subjected to.
